evidence: According to Newton’s second law, the time derivative of linear momentum is force. That means if you want to change momentum, you need to apply a force, which changes velocity.
Here we define torque and see how it relates to angular momentum.
Angular momentum is defined as the cross product of the position vector r and the linear momentum p.
To change angular momentum, we need torque.
This connection shows why the cross product is essential.
This principle is central in understanding precession and magnetization, which we will soon connect back to MRI physics.
